title: Does reality exist, or is it just an illusion of our mind? - Quora

response.answer_text: As soon as I saw this Answer Request I knew I would have to give it a shot. These types of questions are easy to not get wrong. Nobody on the planet can prove either side. By the wording of your question, you’ve taken care of one fact. You ask about reality, as if it were something we can all understand by the very definition of the word. We all, in our minds, have a feeling which corresponds with the definition of the word, ‘reality’. We know instantly of what you’re naming. It’s one of the most obvious feelings we sense. Reality, however, is very difficult to describe. Reality is personal. We all have our own reality. My reality, you might judge to be exactly an illusion of my mind. Logic, for each of us is so obvious to be this, or not this. Obvious logic is only obvious to the individual who sees it as obvious. Too many variables to assume a unanimous reality that everyone sees. We, most of us, get ‘in the ball park’ with something that we can assume we all feel. There’s the qualifier. We’re all assuming that other people look at their life and view their reality much the same as we look at ours. We’d be surprised to see inside the eyes of many around us. Most, if not all, of us have psychosis underlying within our portrayals of who we are. Reality exists because we make it so. We get to watch the movie being filmed, as well as write our own scripts, and develop our characters any way we choose. We see reality as a beautiful experience. Some live their lives in a dream-like state. They’ve been given to and given to. They’ve no idea what it may be like to desire something. Anything they could ever desire has always been within their easy reach. Others, not so much. Others, feel like they’ve been dealt a bad hand. Maybe it’s not even an average hand. Some are born blind and deaf and won’t know what they can’t see, or hear. Those are definitely different realities. Somehow, those realities I just described are all something they would call a reality, and each would be correct to say they were living a life of illusion. My logical answer to this question of ‘Does reality exist, or is it just an illusion of our minds?’ Reality exists and it is just an illusion in all of our minds. Just because it’s an illusion doesn’t make it less real.

Does reality exist, or is it just an illusion of our mind? . Here’s a question for you: Which is more real: the pain in your toe or the brick you just dropped on it?  Well, the brick’s obviously real enough - it’s solid and heavy. What’s more, it’s made from a lump of mud – you can’t get much more down to earth than that! So, the brick is definitely real. But what about the pain? Surely that's pretty real as well! Pain is real – very real! In fact, given the choice between a brick or a pain in your toe, most of us would choose the brick. Not because we particularly want a brick but because we really don't want the pain! So, in making this choice, the pain is every bit as real as the brick - more real even. Both the brick and the pain are real - but they are real in different ways. This means we have two different realities - we have the pain, which is part of the internal, subjective reality of Mind and we have the brick, which is part of the external, objective reality of Matter. Both the subjective and the objective realities are real – equally real. The pain in your toe is not real like the brick is – but it’s not an illusion either. The pain in your toe is obviously a product of mind. If you didn’t have a mind you wouldn’t feel the pain. But even though the pain is dependent on mind, the pain is still definitely real! If the reality of the pain is created or made real by mind, then could it be that the reality of the brick is also created or made real by mind? That’s for you to decide as there’s no right or wrong here… You have a choice between one of these two possibilities: That the objective reality is ‘really’ real, and the subjective reality is not ‘really’ realThat both the subjective reality and the objective reality are equally real because they are both made real, reified or ‘realised’ by mind.Personally, I believe the second. I believe that the black and white distinction between reality and illusion is not helpful. What we call reality may not be ‘really’ real but it’s not an illusion either. Reality – whether subjective or objective – is mind dependent. Reality is something that is reified or ‘realised’ by mind and then seen as real. Reality is something created by mind and made real by it.

This is different than the original question! Reality is real by definition. Illusion of our mind? Or whatever it is our minds perceive? We are constantly using our minds, at least some of us, to uncover a deeper understanding of reality. But in general, we would not call it an illusion, just an imperfect vision or understanding. There is likely something behind our perceptions, whether our understanding of it is that good, or not. I suppose it could also be a relativity problem. Relative to a super-being of some kind, our understanding of reality may be pretty poor. Theirs may be more “accurate,” although it is possible neither are very accurate, just relatively useful. For instance, for living on our planet for the span out our lifetime, our understanding of reality may be fine. But if we were energy moving between stars, living billions of years, we would probably need a much better understanding of physics, but maybe not so much the biochemistry that humans have. I suspect the question assumed some sort of objective absolute reality. THAT may be the illusion of our minds! We would like that kind of answer, though in the scheme of things, it may not be useful or even possible.

This is a very deep question. Science has not determined the nature of reality, “in full.” We as yet do not understand how the world of the very large which contains everything we see, and can measure, comes from the world of the very small, Quantum Mechanics. We know that everything exists because of the function of the phenomena that Quantum Mechanics (it’s extremely powerful and accurate as a theory), but we do not yet know how that world, turns into the world that you and I see. Speaking just about the human body, we are limited to what our brain and built in sensors can tell us. Our eyes, for example can only see a tiny bit of the Electromagnetic Spectrum. That’s what we call, colloquially, light. However, the entire Electromagnetic Spectrum is the same, just different wavelengths that we can’t see. Right now, through the room you are sitting in, radar from airports is blasting through, as radio waves. Are they really there if you can’t see them? Yes, they are. If you turn on a device, and it has the right antennae, it can “see” those electromagnetic waves. Even our thinking and perception of time is suspect and can be shown to be inaccurate in various ways. It is a very deep question to consider “what reality really is,” and as you can see, we do not have all the answers.

Actually, both. What you perceive as “reality” is essentially the interpretation your brain does of the signals provided by your senses. What you see, what you hear, what you feel is not a raw input but rather a heavily processed signal. What you hear can be influenced by what you see (see the McGurk effect[1]), what you see can be influenced by your expectations[2] . However, there is an actual reality independent of your perceptions. The universe doesn’t end when you die. A falling tree makes noise even if no one hears it. Footnotes[1] McGurk effect - Wikipedia[2] How Does Expectation Affect Perception

Before you can tell, first you need to define how real are the concepts on which your question is based. Is the concept of “reality” real? Does “existence” actually exist? How can you reliably tell apart “illusion” from “not illusion”? Is “the mind” itself not “just an illusion of our mind”? From where I stand, none of the concepts you used to ask that question are grounded in reality themselves. All of them are mental ideas, which is a form of illusion. So this very question itself is “just an illusion of our mind”. Drop every concept from it and ask again with what's left. Then look for an answer and don't accept any idea for it, or you will only get yet another illusion, not the “real” answer.
